Subject: RE: [junit] Best Practices [General Topics]
From: Vladimir Bossicard <vladimir@...>

First of all, I think we have to define what goes into Best Practices and what's not.

"Best Practice" should propose ways to better use the tool.  What the programmer wants to find in "Best Practice" is:
- how to write better tests
- how to better organize tests

Neither solutions to problems (found in the faq or newsgroups) nor documentation about the use of other tools (it's the other tools that should document the use of JUnit, not the opposite) should be evocated.  Such documentation is either the JUnit "Installation and troubleshooting" document or a link on the JUnit.org website.

The risk is that you end up writing (and maintaining) documentation for JBuilder, VisualCafe, Kawa, Microsoft J++, VaJ, NetBean, Emacs, notepad, vi, UltraEdit...

What the programmer wants to find in "Best Practice" is IMO:
- how to write better tests (with some useful tricks)
- how to better organize tests

Other topics should not be part of this documentation, but separate articles registered at junit.org.

my 2 cents

-Vladimir
subject: RE: [junit] Best Practices [General Topics]
